5-2C-1: LIMITATION ON NUMBERS OF ANIMALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Dogs And Cats Per Residence: No person or persons at any one residence
shall at any time own, harbor and license or maintain more than two (2) dogs
and cats, except as provided herein. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012; amd. 2013 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exotic Animals: No person or persons at any one residence shall at any
time own, harbor and license or maintain more than three (3) permitted exotic
pets, as defined in section
5-2A-3 of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Family Food Production: The type and number of animals for family food
production that may be kept is limited and governed exclusively by the city
land use ordinances and regulations set forth in this code. It is presumed that
if a type of animal is not expressly allowed as either a permitted or
conditional use in a specific land use zone as determined by the city land use
ordinance, then that animal is deemed prohibited. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2C-2: DOG LICENSING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â License Required; Issuance: It shall be unlawful for any person to own,
keep, harbor or maintain a dog over the age of four (4) months of age, without
registering and obtaining a license for such dog from animal control. All dogs
in the city shall require licensing within thirty (30) days after they enter
the city, or within thirty (30) days after having reached the age of four (4)
months. Dog licenses shall be issued based upon:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Applicant filing a complete application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Applicant paying the applicable fee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Applicant providing legitimate documentation as to whether a dog is
spayed or neutered.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Applicant providing proof that the dog has received current rabies
vaccination.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Tag Requirements: Animal control shall issue a metallic tag for each
dog license granted under this article. The dog license is:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â To be placed and maintained on a dog collar for each dog licensed
under this article.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Valid for the term provided by animal control.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Nontransferable from one dog to another.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Nonrefundable for any reason whatsoever.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Exemptions To License Requirement: The following license exemptions
apply:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Dog owners who are nonresidents located within the city for less
than thirty (30) days; provided, that the dog is duly licensed by another
agency.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Government working dog.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Individual dogs within a bona fide retail pet shop or veterinary
establishment. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2C-3: ANIMAL BOARDING ESTABLISHMENTS; KENNELS 1  AND CATTERIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Licensing Requirements: An animal boarding establishment (kennel or
cattery) is required to obtain a license (kennel license) as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Applicant shall make application to the city and receive the
appropriate approval.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Applicant shall receive any approvals required from the local health
department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Applicant shall comply with applicable federal, state and local
regulations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Applicant shall submit all city and any health department approvals
to animal control with an application for an animal boarding establishment
license (kennel license).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The city provide to animal control in writing the total number of
dogs and/or cats allowed at the animal boarding establishment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Animal control will perform one or more on site inspections and,
upon satisfactory inspection, issue an animal boarding establishment license
(kennel license).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Animal boarding establishment licenses shall be valid for one year
from the date of purchase.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Regulations Generally: A license granted to an animal boarding
establishment:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Shall be kept valid during the operation of the animal boarding
establishment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Shall be posted at the animal boarding establishment in a
conspicuous location on the premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Is nontransferable to a new business or location.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Does not exempt the animal boarding establishment from having to
obtain individual dog licenses for each dog owned by the establishment.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Notice Of Change: The licensee of an animal boarding establishment
shall notify the city and animal control within thirty (30) days of any change
of its establishment or operation which may affect the status of land use/
conditional use permit or license. The duty to notify as provided in this
subsection is on the licensee.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Renewal Of License: Licensee shall make annual renewal of the animal
boarding establishment licenses according to the rules and regulations of
animal control. Late fees will be applied in the event that a renewal is after
the established deadline.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Exemptions: The following are not subject to the animal boarding
establishment license regulation of this article:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Bona fide research facilities where medical or related research is
conducted in accordance with law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Government shelters.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Humane shelter operated by a nationally recognized nonprofit
organization.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Bona fide retail pet shops where the selling of dogs or cats is
ancillary to the retail sales of the establishment.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Inspections: As a condition of an animal boarding establishment
license, the location of the establishment is subject to periodic inspections
by the city and/or animal control. An animal boarding establishment shall be
maintained within general industry health and sanitation standards, and follow
related industry standards for the operation and maintenance of an animal
boarding establishment. Inspection reports may be filed with animal control as
necessary. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)

5-2C-4: BASIS FOR ADVERSE ACTION AND APPEAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Conditions: A license applied or issued under this article may be
denied, suspended or revoked by determination of animal control if:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Application filed is found to be incomplete;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Applicant failed to pay the required fee;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Applicant provided false or misleading information;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Applicant is in violation of any land use/conditional use permit,
animal control regulation, building code or zoning ordinance under this or
another jurisdiction which relates to the establishment;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Applicant is found to be maintaining or selling illegal species,
wild animals or prohibited animals;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Applicant fails an inspection based upon regulations, general health
or sanitation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Applicant is determined to be a nuisance;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Applicant, owner or operator is convicted of a charge of cruelty to
animals.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Procedure Specified: The procedure for adverse action:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Animal control shall provide written notice to the applicant/
licensee on the address provided on the application stating:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The nature of the violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Establish a specific and reasonable period of time for correction
of the violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Any failure to comply with any notice issued in accordance with
the provisions of this section shall result in immediate denial, suspension or
revocation, as the case may be.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â An opportunity for an appeal of a final decision may be filed
with the appeal authority as provided by law within ten (10) days.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Denial is appropriate for application irregularities.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Suspension is appropriate pending licensee bringing minor violations
into compliance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Revocation is appropriate for continuing violations, serious illegal
activities and nuisances.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â No license shall be issued to any person whose license has been
revoked within the prior twelve (12) months. After the elapse of twelve (12)
months, a person may reapply for a license subject to this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Notice: Notice provided for under this section is deemed to have been
properly served upon certified mailing of the notice to the address in the
application.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Hearing: Appeal hearings shall be conducted in accordance with title 9,
chapter 5 of this code relating to the procedure for the appeal authority.
(Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012; amd. 2013 Code)
5-2C-5: REASONABLE ACCOMMODATIONS FOR SERVICE ANIMALS:
The city or animal control, as the case may be, shall grant any reasonable
accommodation for legitimate service animals from the governing provisions of
this chapter or applicable local regulations for persons with a disability as
prescribed by state or federal law. Any person that feels that they have been
issued a final decision that denies a duly requested reasonable accommodation
may appeal the final decision of the city or animal control to the appeal
authority by filing a written appeal as provided in title 9, chapter 5 of this
code. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012; amd. 2013 Code)

SECTION:

5-2D-1: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
The provisions relating to cruelty to animals as specified in Utah Code
Annotated section 76-9-301, as amended, is hereby adopted and incorporated
herein by this reference. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-2: ANIMALS AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful for any animal to run at large, except:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Animals may be at large while participating in field trials and
obedience classes.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Animals properly controlled by a participant as part of a recognized
dog club.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Animals assisting their owner or trainer in legal hunting or in herding
of livestock.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Animals assisting a peace officer engaged in law enforcement duties, or
while being trained for the same.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Animals on the owner's private property so long as such animals are
under the direct and effective sound or gesture control and within sight of
owner or such individual noted above, to assure that such animals do not
violate any provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-3: LOST OR STRAY ANIMALS:
Stray animals shall be governed by Utah Code Annotated section 11-46-103, or
its successor statute. It is unlawful for any person to harbor or keep within
the city any lost or strayed animal. Whenever any animal shall be found which
appears to be lost or strayed, it shall be the duty of the finder to notify
animal control within seventy two (72) hours so that the rightful owner may be
located or the animal may be adopted if no owner claims the animal. (Ord. 209-
12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-4: PLACES PROHIBITED TO ANIMALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Specific Places: It shall be unlawful for any person to take or permit
any animals, excluding service animals, government working dogs or similar
animals, whether on a leash or in the arms of their owners, into any
establishment or place of business where food or food products are sold or
distributed, including, but not limited to, restaurants, grocery stores, meat
markets and fruit or vegetable stores.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Schools And Other Areas: Dogs are prohibited from school premises and
from posted picnic, pond, park, recreation or play areas. This subsection does
not apply to service animals, government working dogs or similar animals used
for educational programs, law enforcement exercises or authorized events. (Ord.
209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-5: RESTRAINING ANIMALS AND LEASH LAW:
It is unlawful for any person owning or having the custody, possession or
control of any animal to, either negligently or with specific intent,
improperly restrain or fence the animal in a manner that allows the animal to
escape or to run at large. Dogs are to be restrained on a proper leash at all
times on the public right of way and in public places. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-6: RESTRAINING ANIMALS ON UNENCLOSED PREMISES:
It is unlawful for any person to restrain, confine, pen, chain, stake or
otherwise tether any animal on an unenclosed premises in a manner that allows
the animal to go beyond the property line, unless permission is obtained from
the owner of the affected property or the owner of the animal owns a legal
property interest in the affected property. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-7: PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY AND PROPERTY:
No animal is allowed to be kept on the public right of way or public property
without permission from the affected entity. Animals walking on the public
right of way or designated public property shall be handled on a leash at all
times. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-8: DOGS ATTACKING DOMESTIC ANIMALS:
Regardless of any provision in this chapter that may state otherwise, any
person may kill a dog attacking domestic animals as provided in Utah Code
Annotated section 18-1-3, as amended, as adopted and incorporated herein by
this reference. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-9: FEMALE DOGS OR CATS IN HEAT:
An owner or person having charge, care, custody or control of any female dog or
female cat in heat shall, in addition to restraining such dog or cat from
running at large, cause such dog or cat to be constantly confined in a building
or secure enclosure so as to prevent it from attracting by scent or otherwise
coming into contact with other dogs or cats and creating a nuisance. (Ord. 209-
12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-10: COMMUNICABLE DISEASES:
No person shall knowingly harbor or keep any animal afflicted with mange,
ringworm, distemper, parvo, kennel cough, or any other contagious disease,
unless such animal is being given adequate necessary treatment to control and
eliminate the disease. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-11: DISPOSAL OF DEAD ANIMALS:
Dead domestic animals shall be disposed in accordance with Utah Code Annotated
section 4-31-102, as amended, as adopted and incorporated herein by this
reference. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012; amd. 2013 Code)
5-2D-12: ANIMAL WASTE:
The person having custody of an animal shall be responsible for the immediate
removal of any waste deposited by his animal on any public right of way, public
place, recreation area or private property, other than that belonging to the
owner of the animal. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-13: NUISANCE ANIMALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prohibited: All persons having custody of any animal or animals shall
exercise proper care and control over such animal or animals in order to
prevent said animal or animals from becoming a nuisance.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Nuisance Animals Defined: An animal shall be deemed to be a nuisance if
such animal:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Causes damage to the property of anyone other than its owner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Causes unreasonable odor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Is in unsanitary condition in its being or habitat.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Is diseased.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Is in heat and uncontrolled.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Makes unreasonable barking, whining, howling or disturbing noises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Chases vehicles, people or livestock.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Has previously been found at large by animal control on three (3)
separate occasions within a twelve (12) month period.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Has been declared a potentially dangerous animal or dangerous animal
and is found at large or found in violation of any animal control restriction
placed on that animal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Is a vicious animal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Severely bites a human or kills another animal unprovoked.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Abatement:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In addition to other remedies allowed by law, animal control may
abate a nuisance animal as provided by law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â When it reasonably appears to the director or his designee that any
animal is a nuisance, as defined in this section, animal control may abate as
follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Either relocate or euthanize the animal after obtaining written
consent from the owner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â If written consent from the animal owner cannot be readily
obtained, the director may file a complaint with the local justice court
seeking abatement of the animal. The complaint shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) Set forth the facts as determined by animal control.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) Indicate that the owner is maintaining a nuisance animal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3) State the nature of the nuisance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4) State the recommended abatement measure sought by animal
control.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Until such time as an abatement can be taken voluntarily or ruled
upon by the court, the nuisance animal may be impound by animal control. In a
justice court proceeding, the justice court may:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) Deny the complaint and rule on the disposition of the animal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) Approve the complaint and rule on the method of abatement,
along with any rules and restrictions relating to the same in the interest of
public health and safety.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3) Abatement by relocation is not a viable option for animals that
bite or are a serious threat, such as a vicious dog.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (4) In the event the court determines that the animal is a
nuisance, the owner shall reimburse animal control for impoundment fees
incurred during the course of the proceeding. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-14: POSSESSION OF POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS ANIMAL:
Any person who owns or maintains a potentially dangerous animal shall use all
reasonable means at his or her disposal to restrict a potentially dangerous
animal from injuring any other person or animal. Animal control may impose
specific restrictions regarding the keeping of potentially dangerous animals.
(Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-15: POSSESSION OF DANGEROUS ANIMAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Enclosure Requirements: Any dangerous animal may only be kept confined
indoors, or in a secure fenced kennel type enclosure that is locked. The secure
fenced kennel type enclosure must be:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Designed to prevent the entry of children.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Designed to prevent the animal from escaping.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Have secure sides, top and foundation that prevent burrowing or
digging under.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Provide protection from the elements for the animal.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Restraint, Muzzle: When the dangerous animal is outside its enclosure,
the animal must be under immediate control of a responsible adult by means of a
restraint device and must also be muzzled. The muzzle shall be made in such a
manner that it will not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision
or respiration, but shall prevent it from biting any person or animal. (Ord.
209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-16: IMPOUNDING POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS OR DANGEROUS ANIMAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Animal control may impound and take into immediate possession any
potentially dangerous or dangerous animal that is:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Not maintained as required in this article.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Outside an enclosure and not properly restrained by a device or not
properly muzzled if a dangerous animal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The animal or its owner is in violation of any restriction placed
upon the dangerous animal by animal control. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any owner of any potentially dangerous or dangerous animal found at
large or who fails to comply with this section is guilty of a class B
misdemeanor and subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012; amd. 2013 Code)
5-2D-17: WILD ANIMALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for
sale, barter, give away, keep or purchase any "wild animal", as defined in
section
5-2A-3 of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exceptions: This section does not apply to the following facilities:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Animal shelters.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Zoological parks.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Veterinarian hospitals.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Bona fide research facility.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Fairgrounds or a circus.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Research facility for educational or scientific purposes.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Facility Requirements: Every facility controlling or maintaining any
wild animal shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Maintain and keep each wild animal in a manner and by means of
protective devices that prevent such animals from escaping or presenting any
harm to the public or persons at the facility.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Comply with applicable state and federal regulations for handling,
maintenance and vaccinations as directed for each species.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Be kept under confinement on the premises and not run at large.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Approved Commercial Purposes Excepted: Notwithstanding the foregoing
restrictions, this section does not apply to persons who have sought and
received approval by the city for raising animals for their pelts and for legal
commercial purposes consistent with law. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-18: WILD UNPROTECTED ANIMAL ABATEMENT:
Wild unprotected animals may be abated in a safe and humane manner under the
direction or with the assistance of the U.S. department of agriculture. (Ord.
209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2D-19: DUTY TO REPORT DOMESTIC ANIMAL INVOLVED IN ACCIDENT:
Any person having knowledge of any automobile accident or other accident
involving a domesticated animal that is killed or injured has a duty to report
the incident to law enforcement and seek to ascertain and contact the owner of
the domesticated animal if possible. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
ARTICLE E. RABIES CONTROL
SECTION:
5-2E-1: Animal Rabies Vaccination Requirements
5-2E-2: Exceptions For Transient Animals
5-2E-3: Vaccination Certification And Tags
5-2E-4: Impounding Animals Without Valid Vaccination Tags
5-2E-5: Rabid Animal Reports
5-2E-6: Quarantine And Disposition Of Biting Or Rabid Animals
5-2E-7: Duty To Report Animal Bite
5-2E-1: ANIMAL RABIES VACCINATION REQUIREMENTS:
All dogs, cats and other animals susceptible to rabies for which a federally
approved vaccine is available shall be vaccinated at four (4) months of age and
again at fifteen (15) months of age by a licensed veterinarian or rabies
clinic. Every dog shall be revaccinated every twenty four (24) and/or thirty
six (36) months, depending on the type of vaccination, and every cat
revaccinated every thirty six (36) months thereafter. Any unvaccinated dog or
cat over four (4) months of age adopted or brought into the jurisdiction must
be vaccinated. Vaccination protection must be maintained on dogs, cats and
other animals susceptible to rabies. Evidence of vaccination is a condition for
issuance of a dog license. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2E-2: EXCEPTIONS FOR TRANSIENT ANIMALS:
An animal owned by a person that resides in the city for less than thirty (30)
days is exempt from this article. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2E-3: VACCINATION CERTIFICATION AND TAGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Contents Of Certificate: A veterinarian or rabies clinic is to provide
a certificate of rabies vaccination for each animal vaccinated, which includes:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Owner's name and address.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Description of the animal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Date of vaccination.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Rabies vaccination tag number.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Type of vaccine administered.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Manufacturer's serial number of vaccine.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Records: A copy of the certificate shall be provided to the owner of
the vaccinated animal with a copy retained by the issuing veterinarian or
rabies clinic for the period that the vaccination is current.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Tag Required: A metal or durable plastic rabies vaccination tag,
serially numbered, shall be securely attached to the collar or harness of the
vaccinated animal. An animal not wearing such a tag is presumed to be
unvaccinated and subject to impoundment. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2E-4: IMPOUNDING ANIMALS WITHOUT VALID VACCINATION TAGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Redemption Upon Proof Of Vaccination: Any vaccinated animal impounded
because of a lack of a rabies vaccination tag may be reclaimed by its owner
upon furnishing proof of a rabies vaccination and payment of impoundment fees.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Commitment To Obtain Vaccination: Any unvaccinated animal may be
reclaimed prior to disposal by payment of impound fees and by signing a
commitment to obtain rabies vaccination within fourteen (14) days of release.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Disposal: Any animal not reclaimed within the prescribed period of time
may be disposed of as provided in section
5-2F-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2E-5: RABID ANIMAL REPORTS:
Any person having information of an animal known to have been exposed to
rabies, suspected of having rabies, or an animal or person bitten by such a
suspect animal, shall immediately notify animal control or health department of
the same. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2E-6: QUARANTINE AND DISPOSITION OF BITING OR RABID ANIMALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Confinement; Notification To Animal Control: The owner or keeper of any
animal that has rabies, that shows signs of having rabies, or an animal bitten
by another animal that may have rabies, or that has been exposed to rabies,
shall immediately confine the animal in a secure place and contact animal
control.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Term Of Impound And Quarantine: Animal control shall immediately
impound and quarantine the suspect animal for a period of not less than ten
(10) days by the division. The owner of the animal is responsible for the
quarantine costs.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Place Of Quarantine: Quarantine shall occur at the animal shelter,
unless the animal has current rabies vaccinations or there exists special
circumstances justifying an exception. Regardless, a person who has custody of
an animal under quarantine shall immediately notify the division if the animal
shows any signs of sickness or abnormal behavior, or if the animal escapes
confinement. It is unlawful for any person who has custody of a quarantined
animal to fail or refuse to allow a health official or animal control officer
to make an inspection or examination of the animal during the period of
quarantine. If the animal dies within ten (10) days from the date of the bite,
the person having custody shall immediately notify animal control or the health
department.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Release Or Disposition: If, at the end of the ten (10) day period, an
investigating officer examines the animal and finds no sign of rabies, the
animal may be released to the owner or, if a stray, be disposed of as provided
in section
5-2F-4 of this chapter.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Unvaccinated Exposure: This subsection refers to any animal exposed to
a confirmed or suspected rabid animal. Wild mammalian carnivores or bats that
are not available or suitable for testing should be considered rabid. The
following applies to unvaccinated animals:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any exposed animal should be immediately destroyed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the owner is unwilling to destroy the bitten or exposed animal,
the animal shall be immediately isolated and quarantined for six (6) months
under veterinary supervision, the cost of such confinement is to be paid by the
owner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A quarantined animal may be released when declared free of rabies by
a licensed veterinarian after the elapse of a minimum six (6) months'
quarantine.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Handling Of Exposed Animals: Handling of a vaccinated animal that may
have been exposed to rabies shall be as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â If the bitten or exposed animal is currently vaccinated, as
prescribed herein, the animal shall be revaccinated within twenty four (24)
hours and quarantined for a period of thirty (30) days following revaccination;
or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the animal is not revaccinated within twenty four (24) hours, the
animal shall be isolated and quarantined under veterinary supervision for six
(6) months.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Removal From Quarantine Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person
to remove any such animal from the place of quarantine except under the
direction of the director. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2E-7: DUTY TO REPORT ANIMAL BITE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person having knowledge of any animal bite on a person or other
animal shall immediately report the incident to animal control.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â To the extent this section does not conflict with HIPPA, a physician,
veterinarian or other medical personnel who renders treatment to a person
relating to an animal bite shall immediately report the bite to animal control.
Information shall include contact information of the person or animal that was
bitten and information on the animal that inflicted the bite, along with any
other facts that may assist animal control.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any person treating an animal bitten, injured or mauled by another
animal, shall report the incident to animal control within twenty four (24)
hours. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
ARTICLE F. IMPOUNDMENT
SECTION:
5-2F-1: Impoundment Authorized
5-2F-2: Shelter Recordkeeping Requirements
5-2F-3: Redemption Requirements
5-2F-4: Terms Of Impoundment, Destruction And Disposal
5-2F-5: Declaration And Disposal Of Vicious Animals
5-2F-1: IMPOUNDMENT AUTHORIZED:
Animal control shall place all animals which are taken into custody in a
designated animal shelter. Animals may be taken into custody and impounded if:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The animal is being kept or maintained contrary to the provisions of
this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The animal is a stray or running at large.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any dog that is not properly licensed as required by this chapter.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any dog that is not rabies vaccinated or believed to not be rabies
vaccinated.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any animal that is sick, diseased or injured.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The animal is abandoned or is neglected to the point that the health
and safety of the animal is at risk if it is not immediately placed into
protective custody.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Any animal needing to be held for quarantine.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Any animal that is pending a determination of being a potentially
dangerous animal or dangerous animal as provided by this chapter.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Any animal that is determined to be a nuisance animal.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Any animal in the custody of any person or persons who are being
arrested or detained by any law enforcement officer. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2F-2: SHELTER RECORDKEEPING REQUIREMENTS:
The animal shelter shall keep a record of each animal impounded as provided by
law and the rules and regulations adopted by the director. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-
2012)
5-2F-3: REDEMPTION REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Redemption Permitted: The owner of any impounded animal or his
authorized representative may redeem such animal upon payment of the required
fees and before disposition in accordance with the rules and regulations
prescribed by the animal shelter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Included Fees: Redemption fees are calculated to include impound costs,
daily board charge, any veterinary costs incurred during the impound period,
license and vaccination costs where needed, transportation costs if specialized
equipment is required other than the standard patrol vehicles of animal
control, any other reasonable expenses incurred as part of the impound of an
animal, and any reasonable restitution for property damage caused by the animal
or that occurs as a result of the impoundment. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2F-4: TERMS OF IMPOUNDMENT, DESTRUCTION AND DISPOSAL:
The director is delegated authority to administer the terms of impoundment
substantially as follows, and subject to other rules and regulations of the
animal shelter:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In accordance with Utah Code Annotated section 11-46-103, as amended,
an animal impounded shall be held for a minimum of five (5) business days
before further disposition.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Reasonable effort shall be made to notify the owner of any animal
wearing a license or other identification. Notice shall be deemed given when
sent to the last known address of the listed owner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any animal voluntarily relinquished to the animal control facility
by the owner thereof for destruction or other disposition need not be kept for
the minimum holding period before release or other disposition as herein
provided.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All animals, except those quarantined or confined by court order, or
those subject to Utah Code Annotated section 4-25-4, as amended, which are held
longer than the minimum impound period, and all animals voluntarily
relinquished to the impound facility, may be destroyed or disposed of at the
order of the director.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Healthy dogs, cats and small pets may be adopted in compliance with the
applicable adoption policy established by the director, upon payment of any
adoption fee.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â An impounded animal that is diseased, overtly frail or severely
injured, or is suspected of being diseased, may be destroyed or released to the
care of a licensed veterinarian, with or without the consent of the owner and
regardless of the time limitation established herein.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â In special circumstances, an animal control officer may destroy an
animal, upon request of the owner, without transporting the animal to
contracted facilities. Animal control may require reimbursement for specialized
euthanasia or carcass disposal costs incurred. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
5-2F-5: DECLARATION AND DISPOSAL OF VICIOUS ANIMALS:
If an animal control officer finds an animal to be a vicious animal, the
officer may immediately:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Take possession and impound the animal.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Place the animal in a proper quarantine holding facility pending
determination.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Seek written consent of the animal owner to destroy the animal in a
humane manner.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â If the animal owner's consent cannot be readily obtained, seek a court
order to destroy the animal in a humane manner.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â In the event the court determines that the animal is a vicious animal,
the owner shall pay the cost of all impoundment fees, disposal fees or any
other fees that may have been incurred. (Ord. 209-12, 9-18-2012)
CHAPTER 3
CRIMES AND OFFENSES
SECTION:
5-3-1: Criminal Code Adopted By Reference
5-3-2: Bridge Safety
5-3-3: Firearms And Weapons
5-3-4: Hunting Illegal
5-3-5: Curfew For Minors
5-3-1: CRIMINAL CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
Except as the application thereof is clearly impractical or inappropriate, in
view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all of the definitions,
requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and sections of the Utah
criminal code, Utah Code Annotated title 76, as amended, with a corresponding
penalty of infraction, class C misdemeanor or class B misdemeanor, are hereby
adopted by the city. Any and all violations thereof shall be considered
violations of this chapter and each such violation shall be subject to the
penalties as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 207-12, 6-19-2012)
5-3-2: BRIDGE SAFETY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Purpose: The purpose of this section is to ensure safety of
individuals, both as pedestrians and as the drivers of automobiles, while on or
using the bridges within the city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Bridge Defined: "Bridge" means the structure spanning and permitting
passage over the Weber River on 6600 South in the city.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Administration And Enforcement:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Responsible Agency: The responsible agency is the city council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Enforcement Agency: The enforcement agency includes Weber County
sheriff's office, or any other police officer, law enforcement official or
other county officer in connection with his duties imposed by law.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Prohibited Activities:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person to dive, jump or otherwise
remove himself from the top or side of a bridge in the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person to stand, fish, linger, loiter
or remain on a bridge in the city, unless otherwise designated. This shall not
prohibit an individual from using the bridge to walk from one side to the
other.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor and shall be subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 207-12, 6-19-2012)
5-3-3: FIREARMS AND WEAPONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Discharge Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge
a firearm, as defined by state law and does not otherwise violate state law,
within the limits of this city, except:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In self-defense;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â In the case of a peace officer performing his official duty;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â In the case of the lawful slaughter of livestock in an area
designated for agricultural use, for personal consumption, where the shooting
is not in a direction and distance that would endanger persons, property or
motorists;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â In the case of the lawful slaughter of sick or injured livestock in
an area designated for agricultural use, where the shooting is not in a
direction and distance that would endanger persons, property or motorists;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â In the case of the lawful shooting of varmints in an area designated
for agricultural use, where the shooting is not in a direction and distance
that would endanger persons, property or motorists.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exception: Items such as airsoft guns, paintball and the like would not
be prohibited because they do not fit under the definition of firearm.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor and shall be subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 207-12, 6-19-2012)
5-3-4: HUNTING ILLEGAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Hunt Defined: For the purposes of this section, "hunt" means to use a
firearm or other weapon to pursue, harass, capture or take any game, or to
carry a firearm or other weapon in an attempt to pursue, harass, capture or
take any game.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Unlawful To Hunt: It is unlawful for any person to hunt within the city
limits.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor and shall be subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 207-12, 6-19-2012)
5-3-5: CURFEW FOR MINORS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions: For purposes of this section:
Â Â Â  EMERGENCY: An unforeseen circumstance or circumstances or the resulting
situation that calls for immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or
loss of life. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural
disaster or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to
prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life.
Â Â Â ESTABLISHMENT: Any privately owned place of business to which the public is
invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement, entertainment
or recreation.
Â Â Â LOITER: To idle, linger, wander, stroll, walk, drive or ride aimlessly
about.
Â Â Â MINOR: Persons under the age of eighteen (18).
Â Â Â PUBLIC PLACE: 1. Any out of door area to which the public or a substantial
group of the public has access, including, but not limited to, public streets,
open private streets, highways, sidewalks, alleys, parks, playgrounds, public
buildings and appurtenant open spaces and parking lots, open vacant lots or
other public places.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The out of door common areas of establishments, including, but not
limited to, entryways and parking lots.
Â Â Â REMAIN: To linger or stay, or fail to leave a public place when requested to
do so by a police officer or the person in control of the public place.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Enforcement:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a police
officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the
public place.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The officer shall not take enforcement action under this section
unless the officer has probable cause to believe that no exemption under
subsection D of this section applies.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Curfew Established; Responsibility Of Parents, Guardians:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Under Sixteen: It is unlawful for any minor under the age of sixteen
(16) to loiter or remain in any public place within the city between the hours
of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of the following
day, except as provided under subsection D of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Sixteen Or Older: It is unlawful for any minor sixteen (16) years or
older to loiter or remain in any public place within the city between the hours
of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., except as provided
under subsection D of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Parents, Guardians: It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other
person having legal care and custody of any minor dealt with respectively in
subsections C1 and C2 of this section to allow or permit any such minor to
remain or loiter in any public place, except as provided in subsection D of
this section.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Exemptions: A minor under the age of eighteen (18) shall not be in
violation of this section if, at the time the minor was stopped by a police
officer, the minor was:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A minor, fourteen (14) years or older, emancipated by marriage;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Accompanied by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person
having the care, custody or supervision of said minor;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian,
without detour or stop;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Acting in response to an emergency;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â On a sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the
residence which is immediately adjacent to the minor's residence;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Engaged in a lawful employment activity or going to or returning
from such an employment activity without any detour or stop; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Returning home from, going to or being in attendance at any
religious or school function, organized dance, theater, sport event or other
such associational activity; provided, however, that going to or from such
activity shall be by a direct route and within a reasonable time of the
commencement or termination of such event. (Ord. 207-12, 6-19-2012)

CHAPTER 2
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
6-2-1: Parking During Snowstorms And Impoundment Of Vehicles

6-2-1: PARKING DURING SNOWSTORMS AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Title: The name of this section shall be known as PARKING DURING
SNOWSTORMS AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Purpose And Goals:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The purpose of this section shall be to adequately provide snow
removal and to avoid property damage as far as possible.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The goal of this section shall be to promote and, if necessary, to
keep public streets and highways clear of all parked vehicles and other
obstacles left on or adjacent to the travelway during the winter months and
snow events.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Parking During Winter Months:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No person, who owns or has possession, control or custody of any
vehicle, shall park, or allow or permit another to park, any such vehicle upon
any public street or in city rights of way between the hours of one o'clock (1:
00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M., between the months and days of December
1 to March 1.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â During all times, other than those set forth in subsection C1 of
this section, no person, who owns or has possession, custody or control of any
vehicle, shall park, or allow or permit another to park, any such vehicle upon
any public street when the removal of snow from the streets is necessary,
apparent or imminent, and seventy two (72) hours after the snowstorm event.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Impoundment: Any vehicle in violation of the parking laws set out in
this section may be impounded by the authorized policing agency or department
to a place of storage selected by the agency or department.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Penalty: A violation of this section is a class C misdemeanor, subject
to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 200-08, 2-19-2008; amd. 2013 Code)
6-2-2: PROHIBITED PARKING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prohibited Parking: There shall be no parking except for emergency
vehicles during emergencies and/or city public works vehicles at the following
locations:
6450 South, beginning at the intersection of 6450 South and 2000 East, thence
three hundred seventy feet (370') east along both sides of the street.
6550 South, beginning at the intersection of Highway 89 and 6550 South, thence
one thousand twenty three feet (1,023') east along both sides of the street.
(Ord. 233-16, 5-3-2016)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Signage Required: The public works department is directed to prepare
and install signs along 6450 South to mark the boundaries of the no parking
zone established by this section.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Towing Authorized: The city may tow any vehicle parked in violation of
this section and may assess to the owner or driver of said vehicle any and all
reasonable towing charges incurred by the city. (Ord. 195-06, 12-19-2006)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Penalty: Violation of this section shall be an infraction, subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 195-06, 12-19-2006; amd. 2013 Code)
6-2-3: LARGE TRUCKS PROHIBITED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â There shall be no large trucks with a Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) of ten
(10) tons or more allowed at the following location:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Combe Road, beginning at the intersection of Combe Road and Highway 89,
thence one half mile or twenty six hundred and forty feet (2640') east to the
top of the street.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exemptions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Class C Motorhomes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Uintah City residential deliveries. (Ord. 254-19, 12-3-2019)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:

7-1-1: OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to remain standing, lying or sitting on the
street or highway in such a manner as to obstruct the free passage of vehicular
or pedestrian traffic thereon, or wilfully to remain standing, lying or sitting
thereon in said manner for more than one minute after being requested to move
by any police officer, or wilfully to remain on such street or highways in such
a manner as to obstruct the free passage of any person or vehicle into or out
of any property abutting upon said street or highways or any property having
access to said street or highways. (Ord. 66-81, 6-2-1981)
7-1-2: UNAUTHORIZED OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Private Street Defined: As used in this section, "private street" means
a street over which private persons have an easement to travel and does not
include driveways, paths or other ways over which no one has a right to travel,
except by license.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Prohibited Operation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It is unlawful for any person to operate any type of motor vehicle
(including, but not limited to, motorcycles, trail bikes, dune buggies, motor
scooters or jeeps) upon the private property of another, except a highway or
private street, without first obtaining the written permission of the person in
lawful possession of the property or, if the property is unoccupied, the owner
of such property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â It is unlawful for any person to operate any type of motor vehicle
(including, but not limited to, motorcycles, trail bikes, dune buggies, motor
scooters or jeeps) upon any public property, except a highway or private
street, without first obtaining the written permission of the public entity
which is in possession of such property or, if the property is unoccupied, the
public entity which owns such property.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Possession Of Written Permission: Every person who operates any type of
motor vehicle upon the private property of another or upon any public property,
except a highway or private street, at all times while so operating such motor
vehicle shall maintain in his possession the written permission required by
subsection B of this section, except that if the same document grants
permission to two (2) or more persons, a person named in such document need not
have in his possession while another person named in the same document riding
in the same group and not more than three hundred feet (300') from said person
has such document in his possession.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Exceptions: This section does not prohibit the use of such property by
the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Emergency vehicles;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Vehicles of commerce in the course of the conduct of normal
business;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Vehicles being operated on property devoted to commercial or
industrial purposes where such operation is in conjunction with commercial or
industrial use and where such operation is implied or expressly given by the
person in possession of said property;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Vehicles operated on property actually used for residential purposes
and where such vehicles are there at the expressed or implied invitation of the
owner or occupant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Vehicles being operated on public or private parking lots where
permission to so operate is implied or expressly given by the person in
possession of the lot. (Ord. 67-81, 6-2-1981; amd. 2013 Code)
7-1-3: USE OF CITY PARKS, CEMETERY AND OTHER CITY PROPERTY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Park Hours: It is unlawful for any person to enter or be upon any city
park at any time from the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. until five
o'clock (5:00) A.M., except:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â When participating in or attending an activity sponsored by the city
or allowed under a permit issued by the city; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Persons crossing a park on a regularly established walkway.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Cemetery Hours: It is unlawful for any person to enter or be upon the
city cemetery before six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and after ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â City Office Hours: The mayor shall establish the hours of the city
offices and may change those hours from time to time for the benefit of the
city and the residents. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than city
officers and employees, to be in the city offices outside of the hours set by
the mayor.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Other City Property: Other city property shall not be open to the
public generally and the city may remove any unauthorized person on other city
property.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Posting Of Time Restrictions: The time restrictions shall be posted at
the main entrance to all parks, cemetery and the city offices.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Removal Of Disorderly Persons: Even though the parks, cemetery and the
city offices shall generally be open to the public, the city shall have
authority to remove any person who is disorderly, unruly or boisterous.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Personal Property: Personal property of the city shall not be available
for public use. It shall be unlawful for any person to use the city personal
property for his or her own use. In addition to any criminal penalty, any
person who violates this subsection shall be liable for the costs of repairing
or replacing any of the city personal property which is damaged. (Ord. 171-04,
2-3-2004; amd. 2013 Code)
7-1-4: PENALTY:
A violation of this chapter shall be punishable as a class C misdemeanor, and
subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 69-81, 6-2-1981; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 2
TELECOMMUNICATIONS USE OF RIGHTS OF WAY
SECTION:
7-2-1: Declaration Of Finding And Intent

7-2-4: Compensation And Other Payments
