8-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
following meanings:
CITY: Uintah City, a municipal corporation existing under the laws of the state
of Utah.
FLOOD IRRIGATION OR FLOOD IRRIGATING: Use of water in such quantities as to
cause the water to pool, flood or accumulate on the property to an average
depth of one-half inch (1/2") or more, or so that standing water remains on the
ground for a period of more than thirty (30) minutes after the water has been
turned off or otherwise diverted from the area.
SUPERVISOR: The person who is appointed by the city to supervise the operation,
maintenance and use of the system. The supervisor shall initially be the member
of the city council appointed to oversee water issues. The supervisor may be
changed by motion of the city council.
SYSTEM: The Uintah City pressurized irrigation system, which is established in
this chapter and which shall be operated as described in this chapter. (Ord.
191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-2: SYSTEM AND SUPERVISOR:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Established: The city hereby establishes a pressurized irrigation
system. The system shall be under the control of the supervisor.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Powers And Duties Of Supervisor:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The supervisor shall have the duty and authority to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Supervise, manage, operate and maintain the system in accordance
with the provisions of the city ordinances and any rules and regulations
adopted by the city council;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Authorize all connections to the system;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Keep suitable maps and records of the system and of all
connections, repairs and extensions made to the system;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Supervise the maintenance of the system;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Supervise any extensions or repairs to the system;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Inspect all connections made to the system;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â Make periodic inspections of the system, including keeping
records of the time that each part of the system was inspected;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â Report to the city council the condition of the system, upon
request; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â i.Â Â Â Furnish such information to the city council or the mayor as the
council and the mayor may from time to time request.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The supervisor may delegate or assign his duties in relation to the
system to city employees, as approved by the city council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â With the consent of the city council, the supervisor may retain the
services of a manager or management company to fulfil the supervisor's duties
under this chapter. Any contract for a manager or a management company,
including rates of compensation, shall be approved by the city council before
it is executed. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-3: CONNECTION REQUIRED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Connection Required: All record owners of property which lie within
three hundred feet (300') of a main line of the system shall connect their
properties to the system and pay the applicable fees and charges.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exception: Owners of residential property may opt not to connect to the
system under the following conditions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â As of the effective date hereof, the residential property is
connected to the culinary water system; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The property owner elects not to connect the property to the system
within six (6) months of the effective date hereof, or within thirty (30) days
of the time a main of the system is placed within three hundred feet (300') of
the owner's property.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Later Connection: Any property owner who opts not to connect to the
system under this section may later connect to the system by filing an
application, paying all applicable fees and transferring the required water
shares to the city.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Disconnection Requires City Authorization: Once property has been
connected to the system, the owner may not disconnect the property without
specific written authorization from the city. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-4: MAP OF AUTHORIZED USES; TAKER ONLY TO USE WATER:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The supervisor shall prepare a map or maps showing the properties on
which use of water from the system is authorized. If the city authorizes use of
water from the system on only a part of an owner's property, the map shall show
the portion of the property on which use of water from the system is
authorized.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A copy of the description of the property approved for service from the
system shall be given to the user at the time the user's application to connect
to the system is approved.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful to use water from the system on property on which
the use has not been authorized.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful to use water from the system on any portion of a
parcel of property on which the use is not authorized.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â A violation of the provisions of this section shall be grounds for
termination of the user's use of the system. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-5: APPLICATION FOR CONNECTION AND SERVICE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Required: Any person who desires or is required to connect to the
system shall file with the city a signed application for each connection on
forms provided by the city. The applicant shall also transfer the required
water shares to the city, pay the required connection fee and other fees.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Nonowner Users: Applications for pressurized irrigation water made by
persons other than the owners of the property upon which the service will be
used must be accompanied by a written guarantee of the owner for payment for
services provided to the property. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-6: FEES, RATES, RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Set By Resolution; Uniform Fees: The city council shall set the rates,
penalty fees for delinquent payments, connection fees, inspection fees, and
other charges incidental to connection to the system and the system services by
resolution. Rates and fees for services furnished shall be uniform with respect
to each class of service which is established.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Rules And Regulations: The city council may also promulgate rules for
levying, billing, guaranteeing and collecting charges for the system services.
The city council may also promulgate any and all other rules necessary for the
management and control of the system.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Board Of Equalization For Rates And Rebates: The city council is
constituted and appointed as a board of equalization of pressurized irrigation
rates to hear complaints and make corrects of any assessments deemed to be
illegal, unequal or unjust. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-7: SPECIAL RATES AND CONDITIONS:
The city council may from time to time fix by agreement or resolution special
rates and conditions for users using exceptionally large amounts of water
service or making use of the system under exceptional circumstances, upon such
terms and conditions as the city council may deem proper. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-
2006)
8-3-8: BILLING STATEMENTS:
The utility clerk or her/his designee shall mail a written statement to each
user of the system each month for charges incurred from use of the system each
month. The statement for use of the system may be included in a single
statement for all city services, including culinary water, sewer, garbage
collection and other services. In any such combined statement, the charges for
use of the system shall be separately listed. To the extent allowed by state
law, payment for all services must be made at the same time and the city may
refuse payments for less than all services. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-9: TRANSFER OF WATER RIGHTS OR PAYMENT OF FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Transfer Of Water Rights: Property owners who are required to, or who
wish to, connect their property to the system shall transfer to the city
secondary water rights or shares in water companies sufficient to irrigate
their property. The amount of water necessary to irrigate a parcel of property
shall be determined using standards established by the state engineer. The
purpose of this transfer is to ensure that the city has sufficient water rights
to supply water to all users of the system and to enable the city to secure
state funding for the system.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Fee In Lieu: Property owners who are required to, or wish to, connect
their property to the system and who do not own any water rights or water
shares may pay a fee in lieu of transferring water rights to the city. The
amount of the fee shall be set by resolution of the city council and shall be
the approximate cost of obtaining water rights or water shares sufficient to
irrigate the owner's property pursuant to standards established by the state
engineer. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-10: SCHEDULE OF USE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Specified: The city has determined that use of the system should be
scheduled to control demands on the system, and establishes the following
schedule for using the system:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Owners of property having an even numbered address shall water their
property on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Owners of property having an odd numbered address shall water their
property on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No one shall water on Sundays in order to recharge the system.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Water Shortage; Authority Of Mayor: In times of water shortage, the
mayor may issue a proclamation adjusting the schedule above. Any proclamation
issued under this subsection is valid only for the year in which it is made.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Amendment Of Schedule: The city council may alter the schedule above by
a resolution. An amendment by resolution of the city council shall be permanent
unless stated otherwise in the resolution. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-11: CONNECTIONS AND EXTENSIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Permit Required: No connection shall be made to the system and no
extension shall be made to any installation served by the system until a permit
has been issued by the supervisor. The supervisor shall not issue a permit
until the applicant has conveyed all required water shares to the city and paid
all required fees.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Extension Of Pressurized Mains:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Outside Of New Subdivision:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Any person or persons who are required to connect their property
to the system under section
8-3-3 of this chapter shall extend the system mains and other apparatus to the
person's property. This extension shall be performed at the owner's sole
expense and shall be performed in accordance with the city standards.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Upon completion, the building inspector will inspect the
extension.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) If the extension conforms to the city standards, the building
inspector will approve the extension.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) If the extension does not conform to the city building
standards, the building inspector will give the owner and the contractor
written notice of the nonconformity. The owner shall then have thirty (30) days
to correct the nonconformity and have the extension reinspected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â No connection may be made to the system until the city building
inspector has approved the extension.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Upon approval, the extension and all associated apparatus shall
be deemed to be the property of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â New Subdivision Of Five Lots Or More Within Three Hundred Feet Of
System Main:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Subdividers seeking approval of subdivisions of five (5) or more
lots on property within three hundred feet (300') of a main line of the system
shall extend the system water lines to serve the subdivision and shall provide
a connection and a shutoff valve for each lot in the subdivision. The
subdivider shall perform the work in compliance with all of the city standards
and shall pay the costs of the extension and the connections.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Upon completion, the building inspector will inspect the
extension, the water lines within the subdivision and the shutoff valves for
each lot.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) If the extension, the water lines and the shutoff valves
conform to the city standards, the building inspector will approve the
extension.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) If the extension does not conform to the city building
standards, the building inspector will give the developer written notice of the
nonconformity. The developer shall then have thirty (30) days to correct the
nonconformity and have the extension reinspected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â No connection may be made to the system until the building
inspector has approved the extension, the water lines and the shutoff valves.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Upon approval, the extension, the water lines, the shutoff valves
and all associated apparatus shall be deemed to be the property of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â The developer shall also provide water rights or water shares to
the city sufficient to supply irrigation water to all of the lots in the
subdivision. The amount of water necessary shall be determined using schedules
prepared by the state engineer. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â The developer shall provide assurance for completion and
maintenance of the extension, the water lines and the shutoff valves for two
(2) years after approval in accordance with subsection F of this section. (Ord.
191-06, 5-2-2006; amd. 2013 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Requirements For Pressurized Irrigation Within City:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â New Subdivision Of Five Or More Lots More Than Three Hundred Feet
From System Main:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Subdividers seeking approval of subdivisions of five (5) or more
lots on property which is more than three hundred feet (300') from a main line
of the system shall provide water lines and shutoff valves for each lot in the
subdivision.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The developer shall also provide temporary means for providing
pressurized irrigation water to each lot in the subdivision until the extension
of the system to within three hundred feet (300') of the subdivision.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) Such means may include ponds, tanks or other water storage
facilities, pumps and other apparatus necessary to provide pressurized
irrigation water to each lot in the subdivision.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) Plans for providing water to the subdivision shall be submitted
to the city engineer and the plans shall be approved as part of the subdivision
approval process.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The developer shall also provide water rights or water shares
sufficient to supply irrigation water to all of the lots in the subdivision.
These shares shall be dedicated to the use of the residents of the subdivision
until such time as the subdivision is connected to the system. At that time,
they shall be transferred to the city. The amount of water necessary shall be
determined using schedules prepared by the state engineer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The subdivider shall also provide a way to disconnect the
subdivision from the pond, tank or other storage facility and to connect it to
the system when a system main is placed within three hundred feet (300') of the
subdivision. To the extent possible, upon disconnection from the pond, tank or
other storage facility and connection to the system, the lots in the
subdivision should be able to continue use of their existing water lines.
Exceptions to this requirement shall be granted by the city council on a case
by case basis upon the recommendation of the city engineer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Upon completion, the building inspector will inspect the water
lines, the shutoff valves, the pond, tank or other storage facility and the
pump, if any.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) If the extension, the water lines, the shutoff valves, the
storage facility and the pump, if any, conform to the city standards, the
building inspector will approve the temporary system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) If the temporary system does not conform to the city building
standards, the building inspector will give the developer written notice of the
nonconformity. The developer shall then have thirty (30) days to correct the
nonconformity and have the temporary system reinspected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â No occupancy permit may be issued in the subdivision until the
building inspector has approved the temporary system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â Upon approval, the temporary system shall be deemed to be the
property of the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â The developer shall provide assurance for completion and
maintenance of the temporary system for two (2) years after approval in
accordance with subsection F of this section. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006; amd. 2013
Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â New Subdivision Of Four Or Fewer Lots:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Subdividers seeking approval of subdivisions of four (4) or fewer
lots on property within the city shall provide apparatus to provide pressurized
irrigation to each lot in the subdivision.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The apparatus shall be built according to the city standards and
approved by the city engineer. The apparatus shall include, at a minimum, pipes
to each lot, a shutoff valve for each lot and valves sufficient to connect the
apparatus to the system at a future date. All of the apparatus shall be
installed and capped until the subdivision is connected to the system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The developer shall provide maps or diagrams to the city
sufficient to locate the apparatus and to connect the apparatus in the
subdivision to the system at a future time to be determined by the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Upon completion, the building inspector will inspect the water
lines, the shutoff valves and other apparatus.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) If the water lines, the shutoff valves and the other apparatus
conform to the city standards, the building inspector will approve the
temporary system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) If the apparatus does not conform to the city building
standards, the building inspector will give the developer written notice of the
nonconformity. The developer shall then have thirty (30) days to correct the
nonconformity and have the apparatus reinspected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â The developer shall also provide water rights or water shares to
the city sufficient to supply irrigation water to all of the lots in the
subdivision. The amount of water necessary shall be determined using schedules
prepared by the state engineer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â No certificates of occupancy shall be issued in the subdivision
until the apparatus referred to in this subsection has been approved.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â All apparatus installed pursuant to this section shall be deemed
to be property of the city.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Division Of Developments To Avoid Providing Water Prohibited: No person
shall divide a larger development into two (2) or more smaller developments to
avoid the operation of subsections B2 and C1 of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All phases of a subdivision shall be considered together in
determining whether the subdivider shall be required to provide water and/or
apparatus under subsection B2, C1 or C2 of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The determination of the city council on whether a developer must
comply with subsection B2, C1 or C2 of this section shall be final.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Attachment To System In Subdivision: In any case, in which a subdivider
has provided a pressurized irrigation system pursuant to subsection C1 of this
section, the city encourages the developer to design the system to allow for
connection of adjacent properties to the system, and also encourages the owners
of adjacent property to connect to the system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In order to facilitate such connections, the city may compel the
subdivider to approach the owners of adjacent properties about such connections
as a condition of approval of the subdivision. In any such case, the developer
shall make a good faith effort to contact the owners of adjacent property and
to negotiate an agreement for the property owners to connect to the system
required under subsection C1 of this section. The city may require the
developer to document the contacts made with adjacent property owners.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The city shall not have any authority to deny approval to any
subdivision solely on the basis that the developer has not been able to
negotiate connections under this subsection with adjacent property owners.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Guarantee Of Extensions And Temporary Systems: Any developer who is
required to extend the system pursuant to subsection B2 of this section, to
provide a temporary system pursuant to subsection C1 of this section, or to
provide a capped system pursuant to subsection C2 of this section, shall
guarantee the work for two (2) years as provided in this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The work shall be completed and approved by the city engineer and
building inspector before any building permits or certificates of occupancy are
issued in the subdivision. At the time the work is approved, the developer
shall provide a statement of the cost of the work.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Upon completion of the work, the developer shall guarantee the work
in one of three (3) ways:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â By providing a performance bond in the amount of the cost of the
work. If the developer elects to provide a performance bond under this
subsection, the bond shall be issued by a company and in a form approved by the
city council and the city attorney;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â By depositing the amount of the cost of the work with an escrow
company approved by the city council. The escrow agreement shall be approved by
the city council and the city attorney; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â By providing a letter of credit in the amount of the cost of the
work. The letter shall be in a form and issued by a company approved by the
city council and the city attorney.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â If there are no defects in the work and no repairs necessary on the
work for one year from the date that the developer provides the guarantee
described in subsection F2 of this section, the city shall release one-half (1/
2) of the guarantee. If there are no defects in the work and no repairs
necessary on the work at the end of two (2) years from the date the developer
provided the guarantee, the city shall release the balance of the guarantee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â If there are defects in the work or if repairs are necessary on the
work, the city shall notify the developer. The developer shall have ten (10)
days to make the necessary repairs to the work or to correct the defect. If the
defect or repair is such that the repairs cannot be completed or the defect
remedied in ten (10) days, the developer shall begin work to repair the work or
to correct the defect within ten (10) days and shall work diligently to
complete the repairs or remedy the defect. The developer will bear all of the
expenses of making all repairs and remedying all defects under this subsection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â If the developer does not begin making repairs or remedying the
defect within ten (10) days, the city may use funds available from the
guarantee to make the repairs or to remedy the defect. If the city uses the
guarantee as provided in this subsection, the city shall notify the developer
of the funds used and the developer shall replenish the guarantee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â If the costs of making the repairs or remedying any defects exceed
the amount available through the guarantee, the city shall notify the developer
and the developer shall pay the balance of the costs of making the repairs or
remedying the defect. The city may, but cannot be compelled to, expend its own
funds to complete the repairs or remedy the defects. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-12: BUILDING PERMIT:
No building permit shall be issued for a property which is required to be
connected to the system until:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The property has been connected to the system; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The owner of the property has provided assurances acceptable to the
city that the property will be connected before the property is occupied. (Ord.
191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-13: SEPARATE CONNECTIONS:
It is unlawful for separately described parcels to be supplied with pressurized
irrigation water from the same service connection valve unless:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All of the parcels to be served by the connection are owned by the same
person or persons; and
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The city council has specifically approved the connection. (Ord. 191-
06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-14: WATER FOR MACHINERY USAGE PROHIBITED:
No water from the system shall be used for the purpose of driving any motor,
siphon, turbine, other wheels, hydraulic engines or elevators. Water from the
system shall not be used to drive or propel machinery of any kind whatsoever.
No permit for these uses shall be granted without the express permission of the
city council. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-15: APPARATUS AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
All users of the system shall keep their service pipe connections and other
apparatus in good repair and protected from frost at their own expense. No
person, except under the direction of the supervisor, shall dig into the
street, parking strip, sidewalk or other public property or right of way for
the purpose of laying, removing or repairing any service pipe. (Ord. 191-06, 5-
2-2006)
8-3-16: SHUTOFF VALVES:
Persons connecting to the system shall be required to provide and install a
shutoff valve separate and independent of the city shutoff valve so that users
can control service to their properties. No user may tamper with or operate the
city shutoff valve unless acting under the directions of the supervisor. (Ord.
191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-17: WATER METERS:
Water meters shall not be installed for connection to the system, unless the
supervisor or the city council determines that it is necessary to monitor water
use through any connection. In that case, the user will install a water meter
at the user's sole cost. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-18: WASTE OF WATER:
It shall be unlawful for any user of the system to:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Irrigate between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and eight
o'clock (8:00) P.M., without the written consent of the supervisor, except in
case of emergency;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Use water from the system to create, fill or provide water to any
natural or artificial pond or reservoir;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Waste water from the system;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Allow water from the system to be wasted by imperfect stop taps,
valves, leaky joints or pipes;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Allow tanks or watering troughs to continually flow, leak or overflow;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Wastefully run water from faucets or stops or through basins or other
apparatus;
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Use water from the system in such a manner as to cause it to overflow
into neighboring yards, property, streets or sidewalks;
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Use water from the system in such quantities as to cause the water to
pool, flood or accumulate on the property so that standing water remains on the
ground for more than thirty (30) minutes after the water has been turned off or
otherwise diverted to the area;
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Use water from the system in violation of this chapter or any rules or
regulations controlling the system; or
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Use water from the system on property for which use of the system water
has not been approved by the city. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-19: PROHIBITED ACTS AND ACTIVITIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Use Without Payment: It is unlawful for any person to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Utilize the system without paying for the services received as
provided in this chapter; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Open any stopcock, valve or other apparatus attached to the system,
unless it is done pursuant to proper application, agreement or resolution.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Turning On Without Authority: It shall be unlawful for any person,
after the person's service from the system has been turned off by the city, to
turn on the service, or allow the service to be turned on, without
authorization from the supervisor.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Destruction Or Interference With System: It shall be unlawful for any
person to destroy, deface, damage, injure or interfere with the operation of
any part, pipe, fixture, appliance or appurtenance of the system.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Introducing Foreign Substances: It shall be unlawful for any person to
place, cause to be placed or to introduce into the system or any source of
water supplying the system, any matter, substance, chemical or compound without
the authorization of the supervisor.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Cross Connections: It shall be unlawful for any person to connect any
part of the system to any part of the culinary water system so as to create a
potential cross connection whereby irrigation water could be introduced into
any system which provides culinary water.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Flood Irrigating:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person to use any water from the system
for the purpose of flood irrigation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Except for incidental watering of shrubs, flowers and other limited
use applications, water from the system used for lawns, gardens and other
irrigation applications shall be applied through either a sprinkler or drip
irrigation system, including sprinklers attached to garden hoses. (Ord. 191-06,
5-2-2006)
8-3-20: ACCESS FOR INSPECTIONS:
The city, by its agents, shall at all reasonable times have unrestricted access
to places supplied with water from the system for the purpose of examining the
apparatus to ascertain the amount of water from the system being used and the
manner of its use. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-21: TERMINATION OF SERVICE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Termination For Reasons Other Than Nonpayment:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In case of a violation of any provision of this chapter regarding
waste of water, flood irrigation, the use of water from the system on
unauthorized property, or any other violation other than nonpayment for
services, the supervisor may terminate the user's service.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Before terminating a user's service under this subsection, the
supervisor shall give written notice of the termination to the user. The notice
may be given by first class mail or by delivery to the premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The notice shall contain the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The date of the proposed termination;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The nature of the alleged violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The date or dates of the alleged violation; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â A description of the user's appeal rights.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The user shall have the right of appeal to the appeal authority. If
the user appeals, the supervisor shall stay any termination of the user's
service until a final decision has been made on the appeal; provided, that the
user shall sign an agreement that he will not violate any rules or regulations
governing the system and will pay all charges for services accruing during the
pendency of the appeal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â If the user does not file an appeal under this subsection, the
supervisor may shut off the user's service within twenty four (24) hours of the
time the appeal would have been due.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Appeals will proceed as described in title 9, chapter 5 of this
code.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Termination For Nonpayment:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Authorized: In the event any user of the system fails to pay any
charges or fees when they become due, the supervisor may, pursuant to the
procedures described in this chapter, cause the user's pressurized irrigation
service to be turned off. After turning off service under this subsection, the
city shall not be required to turn service on again until all arrears,
reconnection fees and other fees have been paid in full.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Notice: At least ten (10) days prior to a proposed termination of
service for nonpayment, the utility clerk or her/his designee shall give
written notice of the proposed termination to the user.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The notice shall be given by first class mail or delivery to the
premises.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The notice shall contain the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) The date of the proposed termination;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) The amount of the delinquency; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3) A description of the user's appeal rights.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The user shall have the right of appeal to the appeal authority.
If the user appeals, the supervisor shall stay any termination of the user's
service until a final decision has been made on the appeal; provided, that the
user shall sign an agreement that he will not violate any rules or regulations
governing the system and will pay all charges for services accruing during the
pendency of the appeal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â If the user does not file an appeal under this subsection, the
supervisor may shut off the user's service within twenty four (24) hours of the
time the appeal would have been due.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Appeals will proceed as described in title 9, chapter 5 of this
code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Order Of Termination: If the city council finds that the person has
not paid fees, it shall order the person's service terminated and service shall
not be restored until the person has paid all arrearages, reconnection fees and
other fees and charges in full.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Violations: If the city council finds that the person has violated
any other rules or regulations regarding the system, including regulations
regarding cross connection, use of water from the system for unauthorized
property, flood irrigation or waste of water, the person's service shall be
terminated. Service shall not be restored until the city council determines
that the person has taken appropriate measures to ensure that no future
violations will occur and all applicable fees (including reconnection fees)
have been paid.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Termination Without Notice: Notwithstanding any provisions of this
chapter to the contrary, the supervisor may terminate pressurized irrigation
service without notice:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Where there has been an unauthorized connection to the system; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Where, in the city judgment, a clear emergency exists or a serious
health and safety hazard exists. In case of any termination under this
subsection, the service shall not be restored as long as the conditions
justifying the termination continue. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006; amd. 2013 Code)
8-3-22: USERS OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
The city may sell pressurized irrigation water to users outside the city limits
only if such action is approved by a resolution of the city council. The
resolution shall contain rates and other terms and conditions for users outside
the city. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-23: NONLIABILITY FOR DAMAGES:
The city shall not be liable for any damage which any user suffers as a result
of stoppage or interruption of the system caused by fires, scarcity of water,
damage to the system works, mains, alterations, additions or repairs, or from
any other cause. This section shall not be construed to extend the liability of
the city beyond that provided under the governmental immunity act of the state,
Utah Code Annotated section 63G-7-101 et seq. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006; amd. 2013
Code)
8-3-24: ATTORNEY FEES:
In the event the city or any other party is required to bring an action to
enforce the terms of this chapter, the prevailing party shall be entitled to
collect its attorney fees from the other party. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
8-3-25: PENALTY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any firm, corporation, person or persons violating any provision of
this chapter shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor and, upon conviction,
subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006; amd. 2013 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Each day that a violation of this chapter continues shall be considered
a separate offense and may be punished separately. (Ord. 191-06, 5-2-2006)
CHAPTER 4
STORMWATER AND DRAINAGE
ARTICLE A. STORM DRAINAGE
SECTION:
8-4A-1: Definitions
8-4A-2: Compliance With Federal And State Law
8-4A-3: Stormwater Connection And Activity Application And Permit
8-4A-4: Best Management Practices
8-4A-5: Easements
8-4A-6: Obstructions Prohibited
8-4A-7: Discharges Prohibited
8-4A-8: Storage And Littering Prohibited
8-4A-9: Damage To System Or Irrigation Lines
8-4A-10: Inspection Authority
8-4A-11: Monitoring And Analyzing
8-4A-12: Opening Manhole Covers
8-4A-13: Notice Of Violation
8-4A-14: Penalty
8-4A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases shall be defined as follows for the purpose of
this article:
BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPs): A wide range of management procedures,
schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and
other management practices which have been demonstrated to effectively control
the quality and/or quantity of stormwater runoff and which are compatible with
the planned land use. BMPs also include treatment requirements, operating
procedures and practices to control site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or
water disposal, or drainage from raw material storage. A list of sample BMPs
can be found in the Uintah City stormwater management plan currently in effect
(available at the Uintah City public office).
CATCH BASIN: A drain inlet designed to keep out large or obstructive matter.
CLEAN WATER ACT: The federal water pollution prevention and control act, 33 USC
1251 et seq.
DEBRIS: Any dirt, rock, sand, vegetation, rubbish or litter.
DETENTION BASIN: A depression designed to detain stormwater runoff until
downstream storm sewer resources are less heavily taxed. A detention basin
contains an inlet and an outlet, allows debris to settle out, and regulates
water flow.
DEVELOPMENT: Any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate,
including, but not limited to, site preparation, filling, grading, paving,
excavation and construction of buildings or other structures.
DIRECTOR: The public works director of Uintah City or his/her duly appointed
deputy, agent or representative.
DISTURB: To alter the physical condition, natural terrain or vegetation of land
by clearing, grubbing, grading, excavating, filling, building or other
construction activity.
DRAIN INLET: A point of entry into a sump, detention basin or storm drain
system.
EPA: Environmental protection agency.
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: Any material, including any substance or waste, or
combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical,
chemical or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute
to, a substantial presence or potential hazard to human health, safety,
property or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported,
disposed of, or otherwise managed. Hazardous material includes, but is not
limited to, any hazardous substance designated under 40 CFR part 118, pursuant
to section 311 of the clean water act.
ILLICIT CONNECTION: Either of the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, which
allows an illicit discharge to enter the storm drain system. Examples include,
but are not limited to, any conveyances which allow nonstormwater discharge,
such as sewage, process wastewater or wash water to enter the storm drain
system, and any connections to the storm drain system from indoor drains or
sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had been previously
allowed, permitted or approved by a government agency; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any drain or conveyance connected to or discharging to the storm drain
system, which has not been:
1. Documented in plans, maps or equivalent records submitted to the city; and
2. Approved in writing by the city.
ILLICIT DISCHARGE: Any nonstormwater discharge to the storm sewer system.
Illicit discharges include both direct connections (e.g., wastewater piping
either mistakenly or deliberately connected to the storm sewer system) and
indirect connections (e.g., infiltration into the storm sewer system or spills
collected by drain inlets).
LAND DEVELOPMENT: Any development of a parcel, lot, subdivision plat or site
plan. If there is more than one lot in the subdivision plat or site plan, all
lots in the subdivision plat or site plan shall jointly be considered to be
part of the land development.
NPDES: National pollutant discharge elimination system.
NONSTORMWATER RUNOFF: Any runoff other than stormwater.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, partnership, association, company or body
politic, including any agency of the state of Utah and the United States
government.
POLLUTANT: Dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, filter backwash,
sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological
materials, radioactive materials, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand,
cellar dirt, industrial, municipal and agricultural waste, paints, varnishes
and solvents; oil and other automotive fluids; nonhazardous liquid and solid
wastes and yard wastes; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter or other discarded or
abandoned objects, articles and accumulations that may cause or contribute to
pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides and fertilizers; hazardous
substances and wastes; sewage, fecal coliform and pathogens; dissolved and
particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from
constructing a building or structure (including, but not limited to, sediments,
slurries and concrete resinates); and noxious or offensive matter of any kind.
REDEVELOPMENT: Alterations of a property that change the footprint of a site or
building in such a way that disturbs one acre of land or more.
STORM DRAIN: A closed conduit for conducting collected stormwater.
STORM SEWER SYSTEM: The system of conveyances (including sidewalks, roads with
drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, detention basins, curbs,
gutters, ditches, manmade channels, sumps, storm drains and groundwater) owned
and operated by the city, which is designed and used for collecting or
conveying stormwater. The "storm sewer system" is also referred to as a
"municipal separate storm sewer system" or "MS4".
STORMWATER: Any flow that occurs during or following any form of natural
precipitation. Stormwater includes only the portion of such flow that is
composed of precipitation.
STORMWATER RUNOFF: Water that is generated by stormwater flows over land.
SUMP: A formalized underground structure, surrounded by drain rock that acts as
a detention basin to allow the slow release of water into the surrounding
subsoil. Sumps usually receive stormwater runoff from paved areas, such as
streets, parking lots, building roofs, etc. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003; amd. 2013
Code)
8-4A-2: COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE LAW:
Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to relieve any person from an
obligation to comply with an applicable federal, state or local law relating to
stormwater discharges or drinking water protection. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-3: STORMWATER CONNECTION AND ACTIVITY APPLICATION AND PERMIT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Permit Required: No person shall connect to the city storm sewer
system, either directly or indirectly, without first obtaining a city
stormwater connection and activity application and permit from the city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â When Permit Required: Any person beginning new construction
(development of an undeveloped parcel) or "redevelopment", as defined in
section
8-4A-1 of this article, in the city shall obtain a city stormwater connection
and activity application and permit before commencing construction.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Application: The applicant for a city stormwater connection and
activity application and permit shall submit the following to the city:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Application Form: A completed application form. Application forms
will be available at the city office.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â BMPs Plan: A plan incorporating stormwater BMPs that meet the
requirements of section
8-4A-4 of this article.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Maintenance Plan: A plan outlining how the applicant will maintain
the stormwater improvements listed in the application.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Fee: A fee in an amount set by resolution of the city council. (Ord.
169-03, 12-2-2003)
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Review: The city stormwater connection and activity application and
permit shall be reviewed by the director and either approved, approved with
conditions or denied. Either the permit applicant or the city may appeal the
director's decision to the appeal authority. The appeal shall be made according
to procedures established in section
8-4B-10 of this chapter. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Factors: When deciding whether to approve, conditionally approve or
deny a city stormwater connection and activity application and permit
application, the following factors shall be considered:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Whether the application complies with applicable city ordinances and
policies.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whether the application complies with the city storm management
plan. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Whether the application complies with the master plan of the city.
(Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Whether the proposed connection incorporates effective best
management practices.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Whether the proposed connection introduces pollutants into the storm
drain system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Whether the proposed connection creates a safety hazard.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Whether the proposed connection affects the integrity of the storm
sewer system infrastructure.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Whether the proposed connection endangers the city drinking water.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Whether the applicant has submitted a maintenance plan ensuring the
proper maintenance and upkeep of the applicant's connection and on site
stormwater improvements.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Failure Deemed Violation: Failure to construct or maintain stormwater
improvements in accordance with an approved city stormwater connection and
activity application and permit shall be a violation of this article.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â As Built Plans: Any person connecting to the storm sewer system shall
provide the city with as built plans showing the details and the location of
the connection. The plans shall be in a format that is acceptable to the city.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Rate: Connections to the storm sewer system shall be designed so that
the discharge to the storm sewer system does not exceed two-tenths (0.2) cubic
feet per second per acre.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Exempt Connections: The following connections to the storm sewer system
are exempt from the permitting requirements of this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Connections from single-family residences; provided, that the runoff
from the residences is handled according to a plat or site plan approved by the
city. However, any person desiring to use a basement pump, foundation drain or
other related fixture directly or indirectly connecting to the storm sewer
system must obtain a city stormwater connection and activity application and
permit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Connections made by the city. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-4: BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES:
Any person connecting to the storm sewer system or developing a commercial or
industrial site shall employ best management practices (BMPs) approved by the
city. The city shall adopt a policy establishing a menu of BMPs that may be
used to satisfy this requirement. The BMPs may be structural and/or
nonstructural, depending on the needs of the site. The BMPs shall be designed
to ensure that the quality and quantity of stormwater released to the city
storm sewer system meets the requirements of federal, state and local laws and
regulations, and the city NPDES permit, and will not exceed the designed
capacity of the storm sewer system or jeopardize the integrity of the storm
sewer system. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-5: EASEMENTS:
The director may enter all private properties through which the city holds an
easement for the purposes of inspecting, observing, measuring, sampling,
repairing or maintaining any portion of the storm sewer facilities lying within
the easement, or the performance of any other duties pertinent to the operation
of the storm sewer system. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-6: OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Specified: It is unlawful for any person to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Obstruct the flow of water in the storm sewer system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Contribute to the obstruction of the flow of water in the storm
sewer system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Cover or obstruct any drain inlet.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exemptions: The following obstructions are exempt from the prohibitions
of this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Street and/or storm sewer improvement projects authorized by the
city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Flood control and prevention activities performed by the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Obstructions approved by the city as part of a site stormwater
drainage plan.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Obstructions occurring during cleanup periods established by the
city; provided, that the materials are placed according to city directions and
do not obstruct drain inlets. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-7: DISCHARGES PROHIBITED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Specified: It is unlawful for any person to cause or allow an illicit
discharge to the storm sewer system.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exemptions: The following discharges to the storm sewer system are
exempt from the prohibitions of this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Discharges regulated under a valid national pollutant discharge
elimination system (NPDES) storm discharge permit; provided, that the discharge
complies with the terms of the permit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Discharges from water line flushing performed by the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Discharges from sprinkled landscape irrigation or sprinkled lawn
watering.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Discharges from individual residential car washing; provided, that a
biodegradable detergent is used.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Discharges from natural riparian habitat or wetland flows.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Discharges from natural groundwater flows.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Discharges from air conditioning condensation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Discharges from firefighting or emergency management activities.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Discharges from swimming pools constructed prior to April 10, 1990.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Discharges from foundation drains, footing drains, or crawl space
or basement pumps if the discharges have been approved in writing by the city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Discharges allowed by a city stormwater connection and activity
application and permit. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-8: STORAGE AND LITTERING PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to maintain, store, keep, deposit or leave any
pollutant or hazardous material, or any item containing a pollutant or
hazardous material, in a manner that is likely to result in the discharge of
the pollutant or hazardous material to the storm sewer system. (Ord. 169-03,
12-2-2003)
8-4A-9: DAMAGE TO SYSTEM OR IRRIGATION LINES:
Any person who damages any portion of the storm sewer system, a city owned
irrigation line or a city maintained irrigation line shall be responsible for
repairing the damages. The damages shall be repaired by a licensed contractor
bonded to do work in the city and shall be repaired in accordance with the
city's construction standards and specifications. It is unlawful to remove or
alter any portion of the storm sewer system without permission from the
director. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-10: INSPECTION AUTHORITY:
Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any provision of this
article, or whenever the city has cause to believe that there exists, or
potentially exists, a condition which constitutes a violation of this article,
the city may enter the premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same and
to inspect and copy records related to stormwater compliance. In the event the
owner or occupant refuses entry after a request to enter and inspect has been
made, the city is hereby empowered to seek assistance from any court of
competent jurisdiction in obtaining such entry. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-11: MONITORING AND ANALYZING:
If city tests or inspections indicate that a site is causing or contributing to
stormwater pollution, illegal discharges and/or nonstormwater discharges to the
storm sewer system or waters of the United States, and if the violations
continue after notice from the city, the city may require any person engaged in
the illicit activity and/or the owner or operator of the site to provide, at
their own expense, monitoring and analyses required by the city to determine
compliance with this article. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-12: OPENING MANHOLE COVERS:
It shall be unlawful to open any storm sewer manhole or other storm sewer
fixture (such as grates, lids or inlets) without permission from the director.
(Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-13: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Requirements Of Notice: Whenever the city finds that a person has
violated a prohibition or failed to comply with a requirement of this article,
the city will order compliance by written notice of violation to the
responsible person. Such notice may require without limitation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The performance of monitoring, analyses and reporting;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The elimination of illicit connections or discharges;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â That violating discharges, practices or operations shall cease and
desist;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The abatement or remediation of stormwater pollution or
contamination hazards and the restoration of any affected property;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Payment to cover administrative, remediation, monitoring, analyses
and reporting costs; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The implementation of source control or treatment BMPs.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exception To Notice Requirement: The city may skip the notice
requirements set forth in this section and immediately proceed with criminal
and/or civil action against the violator if:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The violator has committed the same violation in the past;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The violation, in the opinion of the city, creates a serious risk to
persons, the environment or property; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The city deems the violation to constitute an emergency. (Ord. 169-
03, 12-2-2003)
8-4A-14: PENALTY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The violation of any provision of this article is a class B misdemeanor
and, upon conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a
separate offense. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If, as the result of the violation of any provision of this article,
the city or any other party suffers damages and is required to make repairs
and/or replace any materials, the cost of repair and/or replacement shall be
borne by the violating party and shall be in addition to any criminal or civil
fines and/or penalties.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Violators of this article may also be subject to prosecution, fines and
penalties from the state and the United States EPA. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
ARTICLE B. STORMWATER CONNECTION AND ACTIVITY APPLICATION AND PERMIT
SECTION:
8-4B-1: Purpose And Intent
8-4B-2: Compliance With Federal And State Law

8-4B-4: Application For Permit
8-4B-5: Exemptions

8-4B-7: Proper Operation And Maintenance

8-4B-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this article is to prevent the discharge of sediment and other
construction related pollutants from construction sites. Sediment and debris
from construction sites are a major source of pollution to waterways and water
systems located within the city and surrounding areas. Each year stormwater
runoff carries tons of sediment from construction sites into local drainage
systems, irrigation systems, canals, rivers and lakes. Sediment from stormwater
runoff also clogs and obstructs storm drains, culverts and canals and causes
damage to private property, wildlife habitat and water quality. (Ord. 169-03,
12-2-2003)
8-4B-2: COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE LAW:
Nothing contained in this article is intended to relieve any person or entity
from any obligation to comply with applicable federal and state laws and
regulations pertaining to clean water and/or stormwater runoff. (Ord. 169-03,
12-2-2003)
8-4B-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
A city stormwater connection and activity application and permit (permit) is
required before any person or entity may excavate, grub and clear, grade, or
perform any type of construction activity that will disrupt or cause a change
in the natural landscape upon any of the following types of property located
within the city:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â One Acre Or More: Any parcel, lot or land development which is equal to
or greater than one acre (43,560 square feet) in size. A subdivision
development greater than or equal to one acre in size qualifies under this
subsection even if each of the individual lots in the subdivision is smaller
than one acre.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Special Concern Areas: Any parcel, lot or land development for which
the city determines that because of the nature or type of the parcel, lot or
development, disturbance of the land is likely to result in erosion or the
transport of sediment off of the site by stormwater to a degree substantially
greater than that which would occur under natural landscape conditions. (Ord.
169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4B-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person or entity desiring a permit must first file an application with the
city office. The application may be submitted independently, or as part of an
application for a subdivision preliminary site plan approval, site plan
approval or building permit.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Content: The application shall include a stormwater pollution
prevention plan which meets the criteria set forth in section
8-4B-6 of this article.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Time Of Filing: The applicant shall file the application on or before
the following dates:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Subdivision: The date that the applicant submits the preliminary
subdivision plat application if the applicant proposes to develop a
subdivision.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Site Plan: The date that the applicant submits a site plan
application if the applicant proposes to develop a site plan or amended site
plan.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Building Permit: The date that the applicant submits a building
permit application if the applicant proposes to construct a building on an
existing lot or parcel.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Other: At least two (2) weeks before the developer intends to
perform any type of work not listed above that would require a permit pursuant
to this article.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Compliance: If an applicant's development comes under more than one of
the categories listed above, then the applicant shall submit the stormwater
construction activity application and permit on the earliest of the listed
dates. Failure to comply with the application dates set forth above is not a
criminal offense, but may delay the applicant's project. Failure to acquire a
required permit is grounds for denying a related subdivision application, site
plan application, conditional use permit application or building permit
application. It is unlawful to commence work (move dirt) on a development site
before obtaining a required permit.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Application Approval; Conditions: The director or designee shall
approve the application, grant the permit if the application is complete and
meets the criteria set forth in section
8-4B-6 of this article, and the applicant has paid all permit fees which the
city may prescribe by resolution. The director shall deny the application or
approve the application with conditions if he/she determines that the measures
proposed in the plan fail to meet the criteria set forth in section
8-4B-6 of this article. Conditions the director may impose in connection with
the approval of a permit include, but are not limited to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The establishment of specific measures and controls to prevent
erosion; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The discharge of sediment, debris and other construction related
pollutants from the site by stormwater.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Term Of Permit: Unless otherwise revoked or suspended, a permit shall
be in effect for the full period of the construction activity. The construction
activity will not be considered to be completed until the following events
occur:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Subdivisions: For permits associated with a subdivision plat
approval:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The permittee must complete all required subdivision
improvements; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â One of the following three (3) events must occur:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1) The city issues a final certificate of occupancy for each lot
in the subdivision;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2) Individual permits have been issued for each lot in the
subdivision not having a final occupancy permit; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3) The property has been revegetated or landscaped in a manner
that eliminates erosion and sediment discharge or that brings the property back
to its natural state.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Site Plans: For permits associated with a site plan approval, the
date that the permittee has completed all required landscaping and all outside
construction work associated with the site plan.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Building Permits: For permits associated with a building permit
application, the date that the city issues a final occupancy permit for the
structure covered by the building permit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Other: For permits issued that are not tied to other approvals from
the city, the date that the permittee has completed all work associated with
the permit and takes steps required by the permit to prevent further erosion
and runoff from the site.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Termination: No permit shall be considered terminated until the
permittee submits a notice of termination of the stormwater connection and
activity application and permit ("notice") to the city and the notice is
accepted by the city. The city shall accept the notice if the permittee has met
the requirements of the permit and this article. The permittee shall keep and
maintain all permit required improvements on the site until the city accepts
the notice.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Amendments: In the event that the proposed construction activity for a
site to which a permit pertains is materially altered from that described in an
original stormwater pollution prevention plan in a way that may have a
significant impact upon the effectiveness of the measures and controls
described in the original stormwater pollution prevention plan, the permittee
shall file an amended stormwater pollution prevention plan which meets the
criteria set forth in section
8-4B-6 of this article. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4B-5: EXEMPTIONS:
The following activities are exempt from the requirements of this article:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Actions by a public utility, the city, or any other governmental entity
to remove or alleviate an emergency condition, restore utility service or
reopen a public thoroughfare to traffic;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Actions by any other person when the city determines, and documents in
writing, that the actions are necessary to remove or alleviate an emergency
condition, restore utility service or reopen a public thoroughfare to traffic;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Construction activities which disturb less than five hundred (500)
square feet of land surface area, or which consist of the excavation and/or
fill of less than twenty (20) cubic yards of material;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Landscape maintenance activities on fully developed properties
necessary to maintain the existing developed landscape; and
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Bona fide agricultural and farming operations which constitute the
principal use of any lot or tract of ground located within the city and which
meet the requirements of the zoning code of the city. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4B-6: STORMWATER POLLUTION PREVENTION PLAN:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Required Information: The stormwater pollution prevention plan (the
"plan") shall contain the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Site Description:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A site description which includes a description of the nature and
location of the construction activity;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â A map with spot elevations and contour lines;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â A description of the intended sequence of major activities which
will disturb soils for major portions of the site (e.g., grubbing, excavation,
grading, utilities and infrastructure installation, etc.); and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Estimates of the total area of the site and the total area of the
site that is expected to be disturbed by excavation, grading or other
activities.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Control Description:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A description of the proposed measures and controls that will be
implemented during construction activity and/or while the site is not stable;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The plan must clearly describe the times during the construction
process that the measures will be implemented for each major activity
identified pursuant to subsection A1 of this section;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The plan shall also state the name and phone number of the person
or entity responsible for implementation of each control measure.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Goals And Criteria: The proposed measures and controls described in the
plan shall be designed to meet the following goals and criteria:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Prevent Or Minimize Discharge: The proposed measures and controls
shall be designed to prevent or minimize, to the maximum extent practicable,
the discharge of sediment, debris and other construction related pollutants
from the construction site by stormwater runoff into the storm drainage system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Prevent Or Minimize Construction Debris: The proposed measures and
controls shall be designed to prevent or minimize, to the maximum extent
practicable, the deposit, discharge, tracking by construction vehicles, or
dropping of mud, sediment, debris or other potential pollutants onto public
streets and rights of way. Any such discharge shall be cleaned up and removed
immediately upon notification to the permittee or when it otherwise comes to
the attention of the permittee. At a minimum, the deposit or discharge shall be
cleaned and removed at the end of the work shift in which the deposit occurred,
or at the end of the workday, whichever comes first.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â BMPs: The proposed measures and controls shall consist of best
management practices (BMPs) available at the time that the plan is submitted.
BMPs may include, but shall not be limited to, temporary silt or sediment
fences, sediment traps and detention ponds, gravel construction entrances and
washdown pads to reduce or eliminate off site tracking, straw bale sediment
barriers, establishment of temporary grasses and permanent vegetative cover,
use of straw mulch as a temporary ground cover, erosion control blankets,
temporary interceptor dikes and swales, storm drain inlet protection, check
dams, subsurface drains, pipe slope drains, level spreaders, rock outlet
protection, reinforced soil retaining systems, and gabions.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Stabilization: The proposed measures and controls shall be designed
to preserve existing vegetation, where possible. Disturbed portions of the site
shall be stabilized. Stabilization practices may include temporary seeding,
permanent seeding, mulching, geotextiles, sod stabilization, vegetative buffer
strips, protection of trees, preservation of mature vegetation, and other
appropriate measures. Use of impervious surfaces for stabilization should be
avoided. Stabilization measures shall be initiated as soon as practicable in
disturbed portions of the site where construction activities have temporarily
or permanently ceased, but in no case more than fourteen (14) days after the
construction activity in that portion of the site has temporarily or
permanently ceased, except under the following circumstances:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â If the initiation of stabilization measures by the fourteenth day
after construction activity temporarily or permanently ceases is precluded by
snow cover or frozen ground conditions, stabilization measures shall be
initiated as soon as practicable; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â If construction activity on a portion of the site is temporarily
used, and earth disturbing will resume within twenty one (21) days, temporary
stabilization measures need not be initiated on that portion of the site.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Minimize Risk Or Discharge Of Other Materials: The proposed measures
and controls shall be employed to minimize the risk of discharge of
construction related pollutants (such as paint, thinners, solvents and other
chemicals) from the construction site. Such measures may include implementation
of storage practices to minimize exposure of the material to stormwater as well
as spill prevention and response. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4B-7: PROPER OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE:
The recipient of a permit (the permittee) shall install the erosion and
sediment control measures required by the approved plan before commencing any
construction activity on the site to which the plan applies or at such times
indicated in the plan. The erosion and sediment control measures shall be
properly installed and maintained in accordance with the permit, the
manufacturer's specifications, and good engineering practices. The permittee
shall maintain such measures on the site until the city accepts the termination
of the permit pursuant to subsection 8-4B-4F of this article. (Ord. 169-03, 12-
2-2003)
8-4B-8: INSPECTION AND ENTRY:
The permittee shall allow any authorized employees and representatives of the
city, representatives of the state division of water quality and
representatives of the EPA, to enter the site to which a permit applies at any
time and to inspect the erosion and sediment control measures maintained by the
permittee. The permittee shall also allow inspection of any records pertaining
to the conditions of the permit. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4B-9: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Events For Revocation Or Suspension: A permit may be revoked or
suspended by the director upon the occurrence of any one of the following
events:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Failure of a permittee to comply with the plan or any condition of
the permit; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Failure of a permittee to comply with any provision of this article,
or any other applicable law, ordinance, rule or regulation related to
stormwater; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A determination by the director that the erosion and sediment
control measures implemented by a permittee pursuant to the plan are inadequate
to prevent or minimize, to the maximum extent practicable, the discharge of
sediment, debris or other pollutants from the construction site by stormwater.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Notice: The city shall mail a permittee written notice of noncompliance
before revoking or suspending a permit. The notice shall state the location and
nature of the noncompliance and shall also specify what action is required for
the permittee to avoid revocation or suspension of the permit. The notice shall
allow the permittee a reasonable time to take the necessary corrective action
to avoid revocation or suspension of the permit which time, in the absence of
exceptional circumstances, shall not be less than ten (10) nor more than thirty
(30) days. The notice shall be mailed to the address listed for the permittee
in the application. If the permittee fails to correct the problems identified
in the notice during the time specified in the notice, the director may suspend
or revoke the permit by mailing or delivering written notice of the suspension
or revocation to the permittee. The permittee may appeal a suspension or
revocation of the permit pursuant to the appeal procedure set forth in section
8-4B-10 of this article.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Exceptional Circumstances: For purposes of this section, exceptional
circumstances include, but are not limited to, situations which involve a risk
of injury to persons, damage to storm drain facilities, or damage to other
property or the environment. The city may take any steps the city deems
necessary to alleviate any such exceptional circumstances, as defined in this
subsection, and may bill the owner, developer or contractor responsible for
creating the exceptional circumstances for the cost of alleviating said
circumstances.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Stop Work Order: A stop work order may be issued upon the revocation or
suspension of a permit, or upon the discovery of work being conducted without a
required permit. The stop work order may be issued by the director. No
construction activity may be commenced or continued on any site for which a
permit has been revoked or suspended until the permit has been reinstated or
reissued.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Reinstatement: A permit may be reinstated or reissued upon compliance
with all provisions of this article and all permit conditions, or in the case
of a suspension for reasons provided in subsection A3 of this section, upon the
filing of an amended plan which is designed to correct the deficiencies of the
original plan. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
8-4B-10: APPEAL:
An applicant or a permittee of a permit may appeal any decision or directive
made by the city or its representatives pursuant to this article to the appeal
authority as provided in title 9, chapter 5 of this code. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-
2003; amd. 2013 Code)
8-4B-11: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be a class
B misdemeanor and, upon conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a
separate offense. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Violators of this article are also subject to any penalties that may be
imposed by the state under the authority of the Utah water quality act, Utah
Code Annotated title 19, chapter 5.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In addition to any criminal fines and/or penalties which may be
assessed for a violation of this article, the city shall have the right to
issue a stop work order or to install and/or maintain appropriate erosion and
sediment control measures on any site which is required to have such measures
in the event that construction activity is commenced or continued without such
measures having been installed as required by this article. The city shall have
the right to have such measures installed or maintained by city personnel or to
hire a private contractor to perform such work and the contractor and/or the
property owner shall be liable for any and all expenses related to performing
such work, plus a twenty five percent (25%) penalty charge. The city may assess
said charges against the bond posted by the contractor and/or property owner.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Violators of this article may also be subject to prosecution, fines and
penalties from the state and the United States EPA. (Ord. 169-03, 12-2-2003)
ARTICLE C. STORM SEWER UTILITY
SECTION:
8-4C-1: Findings
8-4C-2: Purpose
8-4C-3: Definitions
8-4C-4: Storm Sewer Utility
8-4C-5: Storm Sewer Utility Fee
8-4C-6: Billing
8-4C-1: FINDINGS:
The city council makes the following findings regarding stormwater runoff and
the city storm sewer system:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The city's existing storm sewer system consists of a network of manmade
and natural facilities, structures and conduits, including groundwater and
aquifers, that collect and route stormwater runoff.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The city's existing storm sewer system does not adequately handle the
stormwater runoff generated in the city.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The city's anticipated growth will place increased demands on the
already inadequate storm sewer system.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Uncontrolled or inadequately controlled stormwater runoff endangers the
city's groundwater supply.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Uncontrolled or inadequately controlled stormwater runoff causes
erosion and property damage.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Uncontrolled or inadequately controlled stormwater runoff hinders the
city's ability to provide emergency services to its residents.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Uncontrolled or inadequately controlled stormwater runoff impedes the
regular flow of traffic in the city.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Uncontrolled or inadequately controlled stormwater runoff poses health
hazards to the citizens of the community.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Stormwater runoff carries concentrations of oil, grease, nutrients,
chemicals, heavy metals, toxic materials and other undesirable materials that
may jeopardize the integrity of groundwaters and receiving waters, including
the city's culinary water supply.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â All developed properties in the city contribute to the need for the
storm sewer system by converting natural ground cover into impervious surfaces.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â All developed properties in the city make use of or benefit from the
city's operation and maintenance of the storm sewer system.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â The state department of environmental quality (DEQ) has determined that
some of the city's stormwater sumps must be included on the prioritized
contamination sources for culinary wells.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â The EPA and the DEQ are developing additional stormwater permitting
requirements that will apply to cities.
Â Â Â N.Â Â Â Absent effective maintenance, operation, regulation and control,
existing stormwater drainage conditions in the city constitute a potential
hazard to the health, safety and general welfare of the city, its residents and
its businesses.
Â Â Â O.Â Â Â A storm sewer utility is the most equitable and efficient method of
managing stormwater in the city and ensuring that each property in the city
pays its fair share of the amount that the property contributes to, benefits
from, and otherwise uses the storm sewer system. (Ord. 184-05, 5-3-2005)
8-4C-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this article is to protect the health, safety and welfare of the
city and its inhabitants by improving the city's storm sewer system, managing
and controlling stormwater runoff, protecting property, preventing polluted
waters from entering the city's water supply and other receiving waters, and
establishing a viable and fair method of financing the construction, operation
and maintenance of the storm sewer system. (Ord. 184-05, 5-3-2005)
8-4C-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases shall be defined as follows:
DEVELOPED PARCEL: Any parcel that has been altered from its natural condition
by grading, filling or the construction of improvements or other impervious
surfaces.
EQUIVALENT RESIDENTIAL UNIT (ERU): The average amount of impervious surface,
expressed in square feet, on developed single-family residential parcels in
Uintah City. One ERU equals two thousand eight hundred (2,800) square feet of
impervious surface area.
IMPERVIOUS SURFACE: Any hard surface, other than the natural surface, that
prevents or retards the absorption of water into the soil, or that causes water
to run off the surface in greater quantities or at greater rates of flow than
the natural surface. (Ord. 184-05, 5-3-2005)
8-4C-4: STORM SEWER UTILITY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Creation: The city council hereby creates end establishes a storm sewer
utility as part of the city's overall sewer system. The storm sewer utility
shall plan, design, construct, maintain, administer and operate the city's
storm sewer system.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Enterprise Fund: The city council hereby establishes a storm sewer
utility enterprise fund to handle all income, expenses and other financial
